title: Shooting spot was not actually Bangladesh, environment, accent is more likely Kolkata, India.
text: The environment is wrong. Sure Dhaka has slums and dirty places, but most of the city is developed enough with an actual nice road system. If they set the scene somewhere else in Bangladesh, it would've been more convincing. The roads are basically dirt roads in this movie where Dhaka has one of the best road systems in the Country. Dhaka doesn't have that kinda dense jungle anywhere near the city, certainly not near the Buriganga river.The criminal class in Bangladesh is completely different. This isn't Africa, people don't employ child soldiers here. And certainly carry Ak-47 in hand and in the open.The Police uniform and looks are completely misjudged. They are trying to portray the elite force of Bangladesh, Known as Rapid Action Battalion. They are not regular police. They deal with counter-terrorism and similar stuff. It should've been the police that deals with criminal or action in the street. Police vehicles are wrong. Don't get me wrong, the entire movie is brilliantly shot and exceptionally action-packed. But this provides a complete misrepresentation of Bangladesh, as well as the city of Dhaka. People who don't have an idea about Bangladesh will get a false sense for a beautiful country by the misrepresented set of this movie.And finally the accents. the accent of the locals are wrong, they are speaking in an accent that's commonly used in West Bengal, India. Dhaka and People in Bangladesh, in General, have a completely different accent.In one word production team fu*ked a good story.

title: very hectic movie
text:
I had no expectation at all, maybe that's why I was positively surprised. It is really very action-packed. Chris does everything, he gets shot, beaten up, even hit by a car, he bleeds and gets injuries but he just keeps going. No one can stop him. The same must be true about the camera man, who must have danced around the fist fights and run after the characters - this is how it looks at least. It seemed very realistic, I can't remember seeing anything like this before. It was like being in the same room with the actors and really standing next to them when they were fighting each other.
The last couple of scenes were not necessary in my opinion, but it didn't harm the film and maybe, will there be a sequel?

title: Great Action with Inspiration from John Wick
text: Extraction comes from director Sam Hargrave, a former stunt coordinator turned director. Knowing this fact, I was expecting some John Wick level action sequences and Extraction did not disappoint in that regard. The action was fresh, intense and beautifully choreographed. The 11+ minute tracking scene is exciting, even for those who aren't film nerds. Hargrave clearly had a vision for how he wanted this film to look and handled some huge action set pieces with extreme precision. This film definitely borrowed heavily from the John Wick series, and to a lesser extent The Raid. It wasn't quite as good as either, but with the right expectations this is a highly enjoyable, fast paced film. Sure, the plot is fairly thin with a handful of thinly developed side characters, but that's ok since everything else was done pretty dang well. Could this be a franchise for Chris Hemsworth? I wouldn't mind seeing another film in this world.

title: Surprisingly good film with great action sequences
text: When I first saw this Netflix type action film I was filled with doubt, having watched Triple Frontier recently and seeing Chris Hemsworth as the main protagonist. But I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. Action scenes are fast paced, realistic, exciting and have that Bourne feeling to them. The setting is not your usual location either being in Asia (India) for this type of film either, which is usually South America. Chris Hemsworth proves he can be more than just Thor (who he plays brilliantly I add). The ending was unconventional too, it's happy but not the predictable type of ending you see in most action films, it has heart and makes you feel a connection to the characters and why they are doing some of the things they are. Overall a good action film made by Netflix.

title: Very enjoyable action movie and nothing more
text: Greetings from Lithuania.Someone looking for a 1 h 45 min pure action movie escapism should look no further - "Extraction" (2020) delivers. The plot here is paper thin, and you probably have seen it many times before, but hey, what is not broken don't need to be fixed! This movie on the other hand has very good action sequences with hand to hand combat and shootouts. Its like Born but much more bloody! The ending was also good.Overall, do not take this film to seriously, nor look something it doesn't have. What it does have are great action sequences, solid performances (and a one very good cameo) and stunt work on highers level. As an action flick, "Extraction " fully delivers.

title: Netflix's Best Action Film To Date
text: With Netflix series, it's always good to just jump in but with their movies; it's very hit and miss with things leaning more to the latter.This is a very decent action film and probably the sleeper hit of the early summer season. With very little movies being released this summer due to the pandemic; this is a good mindless, fun, shut-your-brain-down kind of flick. The action is believable compared to some over the top Hollywood movies, probably has a lot to do with the overall budget.I'd say my biggest gripe is that the scenes that were finally calm, you could barely hear the conversation between Hemsworth and the kid. I almost wished the subtitles remained the whole time even though I hate seeing words across the bottom (yes, I know it's Netflix and I could have just turned the subs on permanently).One thing is for sure is that we need more Hemsworth led action movies without Marvel being in the title.

title: Great Action movie
text:
Every once in a while an action movie come to life to give us a bit of a thrill, and this movie delivers that the compact scenes are done in such a great way, the plot is ordinary yet the way the actors play their roles are marvelous.
Chris Hemsworth as Tyler Rake, Randeep Hooda as Saju Rav did their best.
Finally, we should definitely see more of this young ravishing and most stunning woman Golshifteh Farahani (God she is beautiful).

title: Excellent action sequences
text: Extraction is an excellent action movie, with superb action sequences and seemingly minimal cuts during these incredibly well choreographed sequences. If you rate this below an 8/10 you should simply stop watching and rating action movies. The location of the story provides another level of enjoyment as the street scenes are super chaotic and for anyone who has spent anytime in India or Bangladesh can attest to how accurate the stage of this movie feels. After watching Extraction II, I can not understand how it has a higher rating than the original. The second movie is very good, but lacks the chemistry of Tyler and Ovi, which makes this film seem authentic. Again less than an 8/10, you must cease writing reviews for actions movies as your objectivity is highly suspect.

title: One for the running around shooting at things fans

Guns run out of ammunition, people lose more blood than is healthy and knives fly around.Somehow all of this chaos sort of comes together. It doesn't try to be more than it is, and is all the better for it. Hemsworth does a decent job with what he's given and the supporting cast props him up well.If you're looking for high drama and twist-and-turn thriller, this won't be for you. If you just want to be entertained with a solid action film it'll do the trick.

title: This movie was good. Story was good. I have no complaints
text:
This is a pure action movie that still managed to find time to explore:
Rakes tragic past that affects him
The kids disgust and sadness at being the son of a ruthless drug lord and being treated like a possession
Sajus love and fear for his family, particularly his son
Amirs mentor relationship with that phycho kid
(very briefly) you get to see a bit of rakes friendship with that other aussie guy before things go sour.
That for me is a lot for a movie like this, enough to feel something with each fight scene. Films like this benefit from simple stories so that it gets to focus more on the characters and action. Logan, The last of us, stories like those involving a badass taking care of someone who needs their help dont have convoluted storylines that would just ruin it. Just a simple end goal, and the journey to it and the emotions and rollercoasters that come along with it.

title: Man on Smoulder
text: If you've seen the redemptive classic Man On Fire with Denzel Washington you don't really need to see this vacuous pale imitation. However, it is different, but only in the most miserable sense...Sure it's gun play is video game sharp (that's where my points for the film score), but it's soul is entirely borrowed, and never quite felt. So, hundreds of faceless, in this case Bangladeshi, people wiped out by a dubiously motivated white super soldier mercenary is always a horribly regrettable clich√© of modern cinema. Bears absolutely no comparison to any historic reality. Unlike the gun violence in the USA, Bangladesh is simply not a gun toting country of child gangs and lawless gunplay. Famously, a warm and welcoming country, and rightly or wrongly, a pretty sedate, and ordered society. Not without it's problems, but nothing like this portrayal.So, regrettably, without local precedent, it becomes a relentless slog of just killing. Human destruction, nihilism of the worst kind. I actually hoped Hemsworth would stop early on, and the film would make more intelligent choices not his choice of course. He was funny in the Thors, but Brad Pitt he ain't.... Wink wink... Of course it didn't change, more faceless bodies piled up, urgh.Its essentially a complete video game fantasy for middle Americans, translated to film. Murdering the foreigners, just an impotent bedroom fantasy about death and murder, and not much else. Morbid fantasy for gamers, nothing for mankind. You know, set one in the USA for once, mow down the cops in scores, break some special forces necks. No? See you at the box office....

title: 10/10 despite razor thin story and inaccurate portrayals of Dhaka and Bangladeshi people
text: What a freaking crazy movie. Just by the tremendous body count, it's seems like Hemsworth & Co. took on the entire Bangladeshi police force and army, with a good portion of Dhaka suffering considerable collateral damage. The story maybe razor thin, and the portrayals of Dhaka and Bangladeshi people inaccurate, it's still a 10/10 for tremendous level of enjoyment. Nice to see another big budget Hollywood action movie set in the South Asia region again. ;-)

title: Overall Good Action Flick
text:
I am from Bangladesh, still have to say its a decent action flick. Its true some of the facts are inaccurate, but nevertheless its not a fact based movie its based on fiction. Cris did a amazing job, the boy as the kidnaped child also have some good acting skills.
Randeep came out strong as a supporting actor. The action sequences were also top noch.

title: Trope-ish but good
text:
If you've seen the trailers than it's all very paint by numbers and know our hero is sad from an obvious tragedy and will have "a conection" with "the kid" that will set our begrudged hero on a more honorable path, but The movie has enough turns to keep one guessing... at parts).
The acting is good enough to sell the miniscule dialogs given.
The action is TOP Notch, I mean John Wick level good.
Theres an awesome 12 minute "one-take" action scene directed by a stunt double/director... And That alone is worth the watch.
Cinematography is awesome.
Direction makes this all the more better.
This is an action flick through and through, so don't come here for drama and character development, there Is some of that in the movie but not so much to cary it on its own.
Hemsworth is good in the movie so thumbs up for that guy too.

title: Life is too short to watch such bad movies!
text: You never expect one 'Marriage Story' from the Russo brothers. This is a truth. Another truth is the whole Avengers series has literally murdered the careers of a number of stars. Scarlett Johansson may be an exception. The role of Chris Evans in Knives Out could be played by anyone, as the story and screenplay both were so tight and there were plenty of powerful actors to sail the boat. Extraction is another sad tale of how you play with the expectation of the common people after a gargantuan success like the Avengers. Chris Hemsworth has been portrayed as a mercenary who has literally killed more than a thousand soldiers in this movie. Was it that necessary to forget every logic while making an action film? If you have ample time in your hand and your Netflix subscription has been lying unused for a month, you may watch this. But never watch this piece of ... with any expectation. Because that is not going to be fulfilled. No plot, no screenplay, no meaningful dialogue- this movie literally offers nothing. Even the sets look pathetic. Do yourself a favor, stay away. Very, very, very bad movie.

title: A Pulse-Pounding Action Extravaganza: Delivers Non-Stop Thrills
text: Extraction bursts onto the screen with a relentless energy that grabs hold of audiences and never lets go. Directed by Sam Hargrave and starring the magnetic Chris Hemsworth, this action-packed thriller is an exhilarating experience that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats from start to finish.From the very first frame, Extraction immerses us in a world of high-stakes danger and intense action. The film's breathtakingly choreographed fight sequences and jaw-dropping stunt work are a testament to the skill and dedication of the entire production team. Each blow, each gunshot, and each chase is executed with precision, resulting in a visceral experience that will leave action enthusiasts thoroughly satisfied.Chris Hemsworth's portrayal of Tyler Rake, a battle-hardened mercenary with a troubled past, is a standout performance that solidifies his status as a leading action star. Hemsworth brings a raw intensity and physicality to the role, infusing Rake with a captivating mix of strength and vulnerability. His commitment to the character is palpable, making us root for him even in the most desperate of situations.In addition to Hemsworth's gripping performance, Extraction features a strong supporting cast that adds depth to the narrative. Randeep Hooda delivers a memorable turn as Saju, a conflicted character caught between loyalty and self-preservation. The chemistry between Hemsworth and Hooda on-screen is electric, heightening the tension and emotional stakes of their interactions.One of the film's strengths lies in its ability to balance its heart-pounding action with moments of quiet introspection. Amidst the chaos and violence, there are poignant and emotionally resonant scenes that provide a glimpse into the human side of these characters. This balance adds depth and complexity to the story, elevating Extraction beyond a simple action flick.Visually, Extraction is a treat for the eyes. The film takes us on a thrilling journey through the gritty streets of Dhaka, immersing us in its vibrant and atmospheric setting. The cinematography is skillfully executed, capturing both the frenetic energy of the action sequences and the quieter, more introspective moments with equal finesse.At its core, Extraction is a story about redemption and sacrifice. It explores the complexities of human nature and the lengths one is willing to go to find purpose and redemption. The screenplay by Joe Russo, filled with tense and gripping moments, keeps the audience engaged and invested in the outcome of the characters' journeys.In conclusion, Extraction is a pulse-pounding action extravaganza that delivers on all fronts. With its expertly executed action sequences, captivating performances, and a well-crafted narrative, the film is a must-watch for fans of the genre. Sam Hargrave's directorial debut is a triumph, and Chris Hemsworth's portrayal of Tyler Rake is a tour de force. Brace yourself for a thrilling ride that will leave you breathless and eager for more.

title: It's been done before but rarely as good as this
text:
With a title that should be the name of a crappy Steven Seagal movie that you'd find at the bottom of a DVD bargain bin, this movie was surprisingly rather good.
Of course the plot is a recycled one but hey! Recycling is good right?Chris Hemsworth plays a mercenary who is hired to rescue the kidnapped son of an imprisoned crime lord.
It's a simple premise. One that's been reincarnated many times before but rarely as entertaining as this.
The Russo brothers of 'Avengers' fame produce with first time director Sam Hargrave at the helm.
I say first time. Hargrave has directed several short films but this is his first feature film.
A renowned stuntman and stunt coordinator. Hargraves has crafted a fine action movie with 'Extraction'. His expertise shine through with some of the best hand to hand combat scenes this side of 'John Wick'.
There's a beautifully shot car chase in which the camera stays in the car so we the audience feel like a passenger. There really is some marvellous direction of action here.
The film maybe basic but the fascinating camera work is certainly a cut above.
After this I can see Hargrave's being in big demand.
He knows how to get the best out of his actors too.
Hemsworth is in full badass mode and sells every single punch.
Apart from his excellent performances as Thor, he's never been better.
Hemsworth has the talent, charisma and physic to follow in the footsteps of Sly and Arnie.
There's not too many genuine action stars anymore. Chris Hemsworth is totally believable onscreen and it's clear like Keanu Reeves he's doing most of the arse kicking himself and not relying on a trained martial artist or stuntman.Presented in Dolby Vision on Netflix, 'Extraction' is a visual treat.
It boasts a 4K crisp image.
There's absolutely no film grain which allows for a digitally crisp picture.
Detail is very strong with sweat and grime visible in every pore. Close ups reveal every hair strand and blood soaked clothing as fine texture.
The movie has a amber coloured filter making the whole look of the movie feel hot, sweaty and gritty.If the visuals are good then we should have a great sound mix to accompany it right?
Well rest assured that the Dolby Atmos mix that is available for those rocking a dedicated home theatre system is one of the best Netflix has to offer.
There's plenty going on up top with helicopters and bullets wizzing overhead.
In ceiling or height speakers will have to work hard.
Surround sound effects are constant. Ambience or action, there's always something finding its way around the soundstage.
LFE is rich and punchy.
Gunshots have a realistic thud whilst mid range sound is crisp as depleted shells bounce off the floor.
My only gripe with the sound mix is that the centre channel, particularly dialogue could become muddled from time to time causing me to raise my centre speaker by a few dB.
All in all this movie offers a fine surround sound experience.
The action scenes are demo worthy.
The film itself was a joyous surprise and one that those with a Netflix subscription should definitely check out.

title: Best action movie this side of The Bourne series
text:
For people like me growing with Bruce Lee, Jackie Chan, Chuck Norris or even Van Damme or the first Rambo or DIrty Harry, seeing the Disney's Avengers series is like a joke or even worse a bad cartoon.
A few years back Paul Greengrass gave the Bourne series a very realistic style that even quite successful really never was repeated out of B movies that rarely get distributed in theatres (John Wick the exception).
Now Netflix as produced a really good one, that keeps and sometimes even perfect the Greengrass style with a lower budget but in very exotic scenarios with (apparently) one long takes (handheld cameras ) action scenes, almost in first person that rarely seeing (or never) in latest movies.
Forget the story; it is quite simple; as it was Die Hard or the Bourne, but the action and quick characters definition is so good that you even care about them in the middle of the bullets and infinite deads.
Suspend your disbelief (as you has to with the digitally enhanced Disney movies ) and prepare to enjoy a outstanding stuntworks, shootings and knife fights as the old good movies had.

title: Exactly What You Paid For

No huge moral dilemmas , but a simple mission of secure and protect. All the cast fit their roles well, the action scenes are well executed and actually have some variation to them compared to other comparable adrenaline packed action movies. Despite limited character development , as the movie progresses you still get a sense of each characters morals that drive them. Again, for what the movie requires to execute the plot this is all that's necessary.Although it's not as enjoyable as the John Wick series for me, it's certainly a comparable in terms of the type of scenes you are going to get.Overall, was worth the watch.

title: Extraction more like extra action (badum tish)
text: Going into this film I thought it'd be a run of the mill action flick floating between a 6 or 7 at best. However I was pleasantly surprised by just how exhilarating it was! It doesn't do anything we haven't seen before but I watched it straight off the back of watching John Wick 4 and I have to say I much preferred this! (Watching a steadily older and slower Keanu writhing around on the floor with his legs wrapped around someone is becoming a bit boring for me) I like that Rake is an action hero who accumulates damage as the film progresses giving the impression that he's a real mercenary and not some run of the mill super soldier one man army. Plotwise it was surprisingly well thought out and I enjoyed all of the side characters (although the old boy with the sniper rifle whilst a visually interesting character could have been fleshed out a bit more) the film starts relatively slow but once Hemsworth gets to the safe house and it all kicks off the movie moves along at a breakneck pace. If you're looking for an action film that you can just chuck on and turn your brain off for I'd more than recommend this. 9/10.

title: All about the action, and it delivers!
text: I usually don't give a lot of credit to movies that feel like a million others, because they usually feel pretty derivative. When one stands out among the rest though, I feel that a huge round of applause is in order. Extraction is one of Netflix's latest feature films to hit their service and it's probably my favourite film that they've released since last year's Oscar contenders. No, I'm not saying Extraction is award-worthy, but it's quite a ride. If you're looking for something new to watch, I think you'll be pleased with this one, even though some may find it too violent.This film follows a badass mercenary who's looking for his next big job in order to keep his mind off a troubled past. Being recruited to track down and extract a kidnapped teenager, who's father is in prison, this mission becomes his most difficult one yet. Tyler Rake (Chris Hemsworth) is the brain and the brawn of this story and if he doesn't work as a character, the entire film would fall apart. Now, even though there is some care put into the emotional moments, Extraction is all about the action. If you're not a fan of too much violence or too much action, then I suggest looking elsewhere.Directed by stuntman Sam Hargrave, who has done many of the stunts for the Marvel Cinematic Universe films, pulls no punches in dropping you right into the action. From long single takes with fantastic fight choreography to the brutal amount of deaths throughout the movie, Hargrave, even though this was his first major outing as a director, was clearly the man for the job. Written by Joe Russo, I felt even more enticed to watch it, and while there's nothing all that groundbreaking about the script itself, it has enough character development to serve the action overall. I feel that Joe Russo could write a few more films that are heavy on the action because it seemed to work here.If I were to explain everything that happens throughout this movie, you'd think I'm describing something else you've already seen, but I really appreciated the fact that the incredible action scenes made this movie stand out. On top of that, Chris Hemsworth and Rudhraksh Jaiswal, who plays the kidnapped Ovi Mahajan, have some nice moments together. There are a few humorous lines to break the tension and a couple heartfelt interactions that gave the film time to breathe. I personally really enjoyed watching this one.In the end, as I said, Extraction won't be winning any awards and it definitely doesn't hold back in the body count area, so if that's not your thing, it may not be for you. For myself, I like a good action movie with likeable characters and this movie delivered on that for me. Sure, things feel underdeveloped and the film unfolds as you would expect it to, but it's all about the action and it absolutely delivers. Purely on an entertainment scale, I didn't have a lot of issues with Extraction, because I truly don't believe it was trying to be anything new in terms of storytelling. As long as you're okay with violence, I recommend checking this one out on Netflix.

title: What a great action film!
text: Synopsis: "A black-market mercenary who has nothing to lose is hired to rescue the kidnapped son of an imprisoned international crime lord. But in the murky underworld of weapons dealers and drug traffickers, an already deadly mission approaches the impossible."Starts off with the usual action trope: at the end, and then cuts to a few days earlier. I didn't have much hope for the rest of the film. However, it surprised me. The film had jaw dropping action scenes, heartwarming moments, some funny scenes and when the films climax came about you were really in the moment with the main characters.The action scenes are masterfully done with some jaw dropping stunts and great fight scenes. The chase scenes are likewise amazingly done with the camera flitting from the main characters to the chasers, passersby, and others driving the chase forward in a unique way which was amazing to watch.Would have marked it a full 10/10 were it not for a few predictable moments which you saw coming a mile off and saddened me for the fact they'd still use movie plot devices like that knowing that we, the audience, have seen it time and time again and spoils the movie when you predict it yourself. Saying that, it balanced well with other scenes where it totally surprised you and left your mouth hanging open with awe.Overall, an amazing film which doesn't fail to keep you rooted to the edge of your seat. Chris Helmsworth, as usual is at his best. What a rush! Loved it from start to finish. Would definitely recommend

Script: Script writer did a fantastic job by just translating english dialogues into bengali with no added spice which ultimately kept it rare medium inside and crunchy outside. No extra scripts or monologues.
Action sequence: Beautiful recons before every hit, scared to death in warfare but still giving one last try everytime. Randeep hooda, Chris Hemsworth and other actors. Well played.
Story: bullseye storyline with only one thing in mind- extract a kid who cant speak bengali from crowded city like Dhaka where three parties are engaged in war.
Photography: 70mm shots on the streets of Dhaka (as portrayed) were brilliant, country style alleys shown with living household, sewers stinking the life out the body, cars blown into pieces.

title: It's like Call of Duty, The Last of Us, John Wick and Jason Bourne rolled in to one!
text:
This movie has AWESOME action scenes. There are lots of intense shoot outs and chase scenes which are directed perfectly and the fight choreography is sometimes impressive. The camera follows a lot of the carnage close up which makes the action feel tight and claustrophobic, However it never uses bad editing or the annoying shaky cam effect. Chris Hemsworth is badass as the main character but he is just a pretty generic action hero that you've seen a hundred times before. The rest of the cast do a good job and there are a few surprisingly good characters. The story is pretty straight forward but it has a few unexpected moments which adds more tension to the film.
Overall if you've seen the trailer and are looking for edge of your seat action you won't be disappointed but you won't be blown away by the story either. It's a really good Netflix film and if it comes out on Blu-Ray I would definitely add it to my collection.

title: Thors (Chris Hemsworth) version of John wick.
text: It's not Thor but every time I see Chris Hemsworth in a movie not of the marvel universe, I think of Thor. This is his first outing in the extraction franchise and like Denzel's equalizer, and Keanu's wick, Chris does not disappoint in any way. What seems to be a difficult child rescue turns into an all out war for Chris as he battles wave upon wave of viscous mercenaries as he weaves his way through to victory. The ending is a bit misleading and gives the impression he dies, but I won't say what happened. Great outing for Chris , I'm sure he wished he had Thor's abilities and hammer in this one but he's only a mortal. No questionable content or nudity whatsoever, the movie is focused on the plot and keeps you on your seat throughout. Great fun. Enjoy! Thor at his badass best.

title: Mistakes everywhere
text:
If you are a bangladeshi or speak bangla you would definitely see how this movie is messed up. There are two major accents of Bangla/Bengali, Bangladeshi accents and Indian accent. Clearly Bangladeshis dont speak in Indian accents but all these character who have spoken the language, used indian accent. Bollywood songs were playing in the households which is not a thing in Bangladesh.
They said Dhaka is surrounded by rivers, which is not totally true. Also there are jungle in the outskirts of the city they said, in reality there are none. Also a kind reminder that this movie highlights the control of a drug lord over the country as he can even manage the armed forces which is a joke. Because drug dealing and drug business is a lot less in bangladesh even less than usa, or other developed countries. Drug is not an issue here. An all powerful drug lord is far from reality. Nearly impossible stunts are at its best which makes me laugh while watching. Also the yellow filter seemed disturbing.

title: EXTRACTION FILM REVIEW
text: One of my favourite movies during lockdown was Extraction. This movie is a Netflix original action thriller and it stars the actors; Chris Hemsworth and Rudhraksh Jaiswal. Although Chris Hemsworth in this movie is a very good actor, he is playing his character like Thor.Here is a brief overview of the plot without spoiling too much. A black-market mercenary (who has nothing to lose) is hired to rescue the kidnapped son of an imprisoned international crime lord. But in the murky underworld of weapons, dealers and drug traffickers, an already deadly mission approaches the impossible.This movie was very enjoyable to watch although personally, I think that at some points, the silence lasted for too long. Overall, this movie really hits the nail on the head for me and it deserves an 8/10.

title: An Impressive, High-Quality Action/Thriller
text: Extraction is an action thriller that delivers exactly what it promises: action and thrills. And thankfully, it has a good story to go with it. Even with so much of it, the action is exciting and so well-done that it never felt redundant. These sequences are violent, slick and show off some cool combat moves that will surely please action movie fans. The camera work is noticeably excellent. This is a movie that would have been great to watch on the big screen in a theater.Chris Hemsworth does an excellent job. The guy has more range than he likely gets credit for. And he's not the only one putting up a solid performance here. I was impressed with Rudhraksh Jaiswal who played the kidnapped son of a drug lord. He not only gives us a likable performance, but a very convincing one. With the beautiful score, which sounds very reminiscent of Hans Zimmer's Inception score, we get a nice emotional tone to go with all the explosions and gun fights. Why can't more Netflix action thrillers be this good?

title: REDEMPTION BEGINS!
text: Being the directorial debut of stuntman/choreographer Sam Hargrave, 'Extraction' delivers on all its premises. For a film I was in moderate anticipation of, I must admit, I was heavily entertained.1. Written by Joe Russo, the plot involves mercenary Tyler Rake (Chris Hemsworth) who is tasked with recusing Ovi (Rudhraksh Jaiswal), the teenage son of an imprisoned Indian drug lord from a rival kingpin in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Whenever I watch action/thriller genres of film, I prefer simple plots and this does just that. The story never feels heavy-handed nor do the minor subplots ever disrupt the flow of the film itself. Each of the lead characters are given just enough backstory to where you feel for them by the time the suspenseful climax comes around.2. The film is ultimately Chris Hemworth's to carry and he doesn't disappoint. You completely buy him as an action star and this film is undoubtedly the most physically intense and realistic action I have seen him do. Unlike Sylvester Stallone or Dwayne Johnson who are rather generic action stars, Hemsworth proves himself as also being a very formidable dramatic actor as well just by the sheer emotion he puts into his deeper characters including this one. All credit to Sam Hargrave as I was completely floored by his direction of each fight scene and the manner in which they were staged.3. Unfortunately, as much as I want to praise this film, there are problems that need to be addressed. For some reason, the krytoninte of many action films are the generic villains and this one is no different. Priyanshu Painyuli plays the rival kingpin Amir who is responsible for the kidnapping, but he never has a formidable presence or seems like a legit threat in the overall story to where the film feels like there is no real antagonist. The same goes for Golshifteh Farahani (Nik) as her character is never fully developed either. The real dynamic is ultimately between Hemsworth and Jaiswal.4. Unlike the 'Fast & Furious' franchise, the action never becomes unbelievably unrealistic or buffoonish to where it lost me. In fact, despite there not being anything new action-wise, the realism and the way the cinematographer captures it all is what has you most compelled. Its been a long time since I've felt such intensity and fear for certain characters during a climax especially within an action film. I should warn that there is a certain level of gore that may make some viewers squeamish as this type of action doesn't shy away from the graphic nature in which people are killed.Had this film been released in theaters, I would have gladly paid to seen it on the big screen. I understand these types of releases are usually decisive among critics, but if you love R-Rated action, this is by far one of the more better ones in recent years. Much congratulations to Sam Hargrave because I honestly can't wait for his next directorial feature.

title: Ten Minute Movie Review
text: In which I watch ten minutes of a truly awful film and write a review.Just because movies no longer make it to the cinema these days doesn't mean that runtimes should be longer, yet most Netflix films go way over a sensible time limit. There is no way this thing needs to go over 1h30min but clocks in at 1h56min, or in technical terms, too long. It's sort of the flip side of the old joke in which two people are talking about aa restaurant with bad food. "And such small portions," one of them says. We have lousy movies that somehow think they will be better if they go on 20% longer.Yet another bloody kill-fest of wonton slaughter in which the protagonist seems to be immune to bullets while everyone else around him is a bullet magnet. Does this movie have as many senseless homicides as John Wick? Some other fool who can be bothered to watch all 1h56min of this piece of trash will have to answer than question.

title: Very enjoyable

That gives it a little more 'unpredictability'.The action sequences were great, especially the 11 minute chase sequence which I had to rewatch to appreciate the camera work in particular- amazing!Sure the plot was a little threadbare and there was barely any character development but I still enjoyed the film immensely.To all the people whining about it misrepresenting Dhaka, so what?? title: Camera work simply AMAZING
text: REVIEW - EXTRACTIONNETFLIX ORIGINALFinally Chris Hemsworth (Thor) returns to what he does best.Over the past few years after Thor Ragnarock we've seen Chris Hemsworth take on more comedic roles in Ghostbusters and Men In Black which for me honestly just didn't work. There were funny moments in Thor Ragnarock and it seems that this opened and hopefully closed the door on comedy.Now Extraction is for me Chris at his best.In summary a 14 year old boy is kidnapped by one drug barron who is son of another, his son lives with an employee his fathers (I'll come back to this later).Eventually we find out that no one wants Obi not even his own father so why did his father employ Chris Hemsworth to Extract him?The fathers friend who Obi lived with was then sent to kill Obi and Chris Hemseorth, why? Surely if he didn't want his son just simply don't pay the ransome, problem solved.So as you can see the story is silly especially as half way through the guy Obi was living with and who was out to kill them both suddenly decides to help, cone on!BUT.........As I've said above Chris Hemsworth has finally returned to what he does best, ACTION all the way!The 11 minute continuous scene starting with the car chase and escaping the corrupt police is absolutely amazing! How the camera transitions from inside to outside the car and following the action, one word WOW!Atomic Blonde did this but this film blew Atomic Blonde out of the water in my personal opinion and the action continue throughout the film.So forget the story and simply enjoy this film for what it is, an action packed movie with simply amazing camera work which has to be seen to believed.Rating 9 out of 10

title: Lite Snack But Very Good
text: It is a simple story, with little plot, but entertaining as hell. Great action sequences, very good characters (and not entirely predictable when it comes to the fate of some). In a time when we are given 8-10 hrs of limited series material to digest (which is good), it's still refreshing to see a two-hour movie deliver the goods in such a short period. It has heart, good performances, and again... amazing action scenes.

title: So Close Yet So Far from a Perfect
text: The action is a ten out of ten easily. Both Chris Hemsworth and Randeep Hooda were very good at being serious, action-orientated characters. Harbor was also enjoyable, as usual. However what keeps me from giving this a 9 or a 10 is they didn't spend a lot of time on the plot. The plot isn't entirely original but has enough unique aspects to be its own. But Hargave, the director, focused more on the action than the plot; this wasn't a bad choice at all as it kept the pace very high and again, the action was incredible; but I can't help but think the ending would have been a 10/10 if the relationship between Tyler and Ovi was more fleshed out.All in all the most enjoyable parts were the action and the shots, lots of great sequences. Maybe a bit too much plot armor for the main protagonist at the end but was pretty believable otherwise.

title: As far as action movies go, Extraction is pretty good.
text: Extraction is an action movie. It's supposed to have exaggerated close combats, gunfights, explosions etc. The movie is receiving a lot of hate from many reviews, claiming that it does not represent the true culture of Bangladesh. As a Bangladeshi, I beg to differ. As a action story mostly set in Dhaka, the movie accurately portrayed the setting in Dhaka. There's a few minor mistakes however. For example, the Bengali spoken is most that from West Bengal. Bangladeshi spoken Bengali is quite different. There's also a sequence in a jungle near the outskirts of Dhaka, but Dhaka is an urban area and is surrounded by other urban areas.As for the story, there are some plot holes. There's no clear motive that establishes why the kid was kidnapped. It's also ambiguous as to why the kid decided to start Chris Helmsworth's character blindly. There's also some awkward camera angles, but that could be forgiven as a directorial debut. The production design, stunt coordiation and visual effects were superb. Hope to see more movies set in Bangladesh in the future!

title: Honesty Review.
text:
I'm sure many found the details about Dhaka not living up to the expectation.
But frankly, this is not a documentary, the viewers knew what they were gonna see... The trailer didn't lie either. It's a fully action packed movie and there wasn't anything meant to be different either.
Don't know what people in Bangladesh think, do they believe it's always USA in movies like Avengers? No they shoot in Canadian cities where the actual setting is far better than US cities - just to give impression that superheroes stack up in the most developed corners of the world.
Similarly, this movie is not about covering the so called some of the Good Roads üòÇüò¨ of Dhaka. It's just an action movie with a context of being shot in Bangladesh. Obviously they had to bring in fake police, combat squads etc guessing the Real Police of Dhaka won't have given directors the chance of bringing in that much actionüòÜüòÜ. Again this is what we see in every other Hollywood movie too - you think they are always so combat savvy and competent in real life in the West? title: Great Action
text: This movie is all about the action, and it definitely delivers. You could certainly pick apart weaknesses in the story, but I feel like if you're watching a movie like this, you want action. This movie has great action.

title: The film surprised me
text: Chris Hemsworth was right at home in this role. He doesn't have to do a lot of speaking, and can just let his actions speak for themselves. Some of the stunt work in this film would not have been easy. When he is required to slow things down and have some dialogue in the odd scene he does so adequately.The film surprised me with just how violent it was willing to be at times, especially in scenes involving children. There were a couple of time where I thought - they're not going to do that are they? - and then sure enough they did. This is a very serious film as well. Very little (if any that I can think of) humour whatsoever makes an appearance.The film does get a little tedious towards the end. You can only watch so many people getting shot without becoming numb and a little bored by it. Also the film opens with a shot from near the end of the film. It doesn't work though because there is no intrigue behind it. This was one of the few poor choices an otherwise very good film made however. I would recommend giving this one a watch.

title: Another cookie-cutter Netflix actioner with some above average set-pieces
text: Currently one of the most savvy and successful businesses in the world, with a model that knows exactly what its audience wants and delivers entirely too that, Netflix have been churning out sleek and fast-paced action films ad nauseam over the last few years, with their new adrenaline fueled tentpole Extraction fitting the modus operandi perfectly.Backed by Marvel hero's the Russo brothers, with Joe penning the script and directed by long-time Marvel stunt coordinator and performer Sam Hargrave, Extraction is an instantly familiar action experience that sees Chris Hemsworth's downtrodden but Thor-like Australian mercenary Tyler Rake end up in Bangladesh trying to rescue the son of an Indian crime lord who has been kidnapped by a rival operator.Anyone that has ever seen an action thriller with a seemingly cold-hearted and depressive central figure, whose also a one man killing machine, will know exactly where Extraction is taking us, as the mission Rake is on goes sour and he is forced to take down what feels like a city worth of bad guys to protect his new mate Ovi.Similar at times to Man on Fire, Mile 22 and filmed in a way that feels like a direct rip-off of The Raid franchise (in what is becoming the normal now for Hollywood films trying to replicate the energy and frenetic nature of those action classics), Extraction fails to bring anything new to the table as Hargrave ticks off a serious of boxes on his way to an all too familiar conclusion.It's not to say there aren't little action delights along the journey Rake takes, with a clearly CGI'd but none the less impressive unbroken action set piece around the 30 minute mark of the film one of the candidates for the best action showcases of the year but there's far too much of Extraction that is forgettable, unbelievable and tiresome to bring it home with a bang.This forgettable film nature is a trend that Extraction lead and beloved Aussie icon Chris Hemsworth needs to pay close attention to, with his work outside of the Marvel universe and the well-liked but financial failure Rush is cause for concern.Films like Blackhat, In the Heart of the Sea, 12 Strong and Bad Times at the El Royale might not be the worst films going around but their far from the type of products you'd want littering your career for too many more years to come.Final Say -Some nice action moments are to be found in Extraction but outside of that this charmless and unimaginative action thriller is the exact type of Netflix outing that is still too prevalent for a company looking to reach for the low hanging fruit too often.2 garden rakes out of 5

title: A movie theater movie from home!
text: If you miss going to see blockbuster movies because of our weeks of isolation, Might I recommend Extraction? The Russo bros. are on their game once again, with Thor himself playing a mercenary in a non stop action packed bloody good time! I would have happily paid money at the googleplex to see this one, but Netflix has gifted us a top tier shoot 'em up! Letterbox format, a continuous shot that lasts about 12 minutes, and Hemsworth proving his action hero status, this movie ticks all the right boxes. It is rated R, and I would normally say NSFW, but who are we kidding. You are working from home, and have been wearing that bathrobe for 8 days now. Get a box of cereal, and pop this on Netflix. You will be happy for the 2 hr. escape. Stay safe, my friends!

title: Relentless Uncompromising First Rate Action
text: Forget the plot, if you like action then watch this for an unpretentious gratuitous shot of adrenaline filled escapism. Hemsworth is supposedly mortal and dispatches the bad guys more mercilessly and in than a Marvel hero. The action is relentless and there is hardly time to catch the breath between scenes. Well filmed and edited - it feels like the audience is thrust right in the middle of the violence but without the nausea inducing camera shakes, quick editing and blurred images. In fact the pi√®ce de r√©sistance is a 'how did they do that?' one track shot. I didn't expect an introspective thought provoking Oscar standard movie and I didn't get one. However I was thoroughly entertained for two hours. Well done Netflix!

title: A weak waste of a Hemsworth
text:
On the positive side there is some good action here, but just as they have made some weak Bond films by trying to make them Bourne movies, this falls down by trying to be John Wick.
Chris Hemsworth is a charming lead, but is mired in sad, obvious clich√©s - you'll never guess! He lost his wife and child, and so he takes his pain medication with whiskey! So hard-core...
Hopefully, the sequel will be more fun, this lacks the wit within the action that John Wick has, which makes the huge kill count in those films bearable. By the end of this, the complete inability of the police and soldiers to hit anything was reaching A-Team levels of ridiculousness.
Mr Hemsworth needs to start showing more care in the projects he chooses outside of the MCU.

title: Enjoyable action movie, nothing more
text:
Anyone who is trying to write a screenplay for an action movie will have a hard time coming up with novel ideas. But these guys managed to pull off a novel premise to unwind yet another action-packed Hollywood movie with an A-lister. and a low-budget cast. But that's about it. Great action scenes, great cast (including the amazingly beautiful Golshifteh Farahani), but with no surprises beyond the initial premise. Not even the fact that the seemingly superhuman antagonist villain/hero who can dodge bullets for 90% of the movie ends up being shot in the face when his deus-ex-machina batteries run out on the script...
All in all, a nicely done and entertaining action movie.

title: It made me upset
text:
The cinema grafy is great but it made me upset bcz(collected):
Just watched the Netflix special "Extraction" starring Chris Hemsworth. I am extremely disappointed with the HORRIBLE misrepresentation of Dhaka. Dhaka AND its law enforcers deserve a MUCH better portrayal in front of the world. Reasons below (no spoilers on the storyline). #ExtractionIsNotDhaka1. Children don't carry rifles on the streets of Dhaka in broad daylight. It's a horrible misrepresentation shown in the movie. If I didn't live in Dhaka myself, I would be mistaken into thinking child terrorism is normal in Dhaka.2. Law enforcers in Dhaka - whether it be DMP, RAB or any of the defense organizations - are NOT incompetent and incapable of stopping two random guys flying in from outside the country. They do their job well, which is why we can go out, visit places, hang out with friends and more without worrying about random shootings (like they show in the movie).3. Dhaka's streets are NOT violent and it's NOT normal for people to fight in public with guns and swords. The movie made it seem like the people are used to things like these happening and somehow it's the norm here.4. An entire movie set to be in Dhaka and not a SINGLE major Bangladeshi character played by someone who SPEAKS the language and dialect that we do in Bangladesh? Are you for real, Netflix? All the major characters spoke Bengali like they do in West Bengal / Kolkata - NOT how we speak in Bangladesh - although they were representing characters in Bangladesh. Why? My mother was an actress, a lot of my friends are too. I'm sure many Bangladeshi actors could do those roles better than any of the ones who did, WHILE speaking our language/dialect.Overall, it's a horrible misrepresentation of the country in front of the world by a cast which isn't even 1% Bangladeshi. People abroad don't know a whole lot about Dhaka, but after they watch this movie, they might get the wrong impression that Dhaka lacks law enforcement and is filled with violence.This is not my Dhaka, this is not any Dhaka.PS: This is my opinion on the movie, as someone who was actually born and brought up in Dhaka. I was offended by how they represented my city, and I want an apology from Netflix.

title: One of those action movies you watch to pass time and then forget about it
text: Just because it's a bloody action movie, doesn't mean that you gotta get every single fact wrong.People in Bangladesh don't talk in that accent, they don't listen to hindi music in their homes in the middle of the day. Hooligans in Dhaka don't use AK-47s. Heads of the mafia don't let wasted kids in their dining rooms.Most importantly, a big foreign guy like Hemmy doesn't just go around talking suspiciously on the phone in broad daylight in the middle of a busy street in Dhaka without attracting huge crowd. Maybe possible in India, but not in Bangladesh.And then 60-something year old leader of a law & enforcement starts sniping and accurately killing people by headshots from quite a distance? Give me a break! That's superhero stuff. Wait..Action was good, but nothing spectacular or ground-breaking by today's standard.

I would have preferred that the movie was filmed in the United States, London, Paris, Rome, Dublin, Tokyo, etc. I have a Samsung 4K television, but the lighting wasn't as good in this film. title: WOOF!
text:
I wanted to love this movie. Indeed, some of the cinematography is well-done. Some of the acting is OK, too. The killer for me is the story.
Typically, I can suspend logic when watching a movie. I am on the side of the movie makers, and WANT to believe what they are asking me to believe. I am a friend to movies. I'm rooting for them.
Optimism aside, this Netflix original is one of the poorest written stories offered by the streaming site to-date. It's endlessly loaded firearms, and the hero's penchant for the double-tap coup de gr√¢ce fighting style becomes lazy after a while. I have heard review that liken it to a John Wick-style, ultra-violent, revenge fantasy. The difference between the movies' approach to killing, however, could not be more different. John Wick lives in a dream-like word of paid assassins, where Extraction exists in a gritty, morally bankrupt reality. The story has very little, humor or heart. At last count, Chris Hemsworth's character kills 183 people. John Wick's body count is notoriously high as well, however, Wick's killing has context. He is getting his revenge. Extraction holds no such justification. In order to save one boy, there are hundreds of deaths. Where John Wick kills bad guys. Extraction, in stark contrast, kills police officers and military troops. Almost 200 kills for the life of one drug trafficker's son. I just don't buy it!

Like seriously locking down an entire city to extract a kid! Sepia/Yellow Color Grade on the movie may seem intense and engaging at first suiting the mood but slowly feels redundant and overdone. After all this said; it's a one time watch for the fast paced action, and the acting of Thor himself and the protagonist child!

title: Extraction Review
text: These action movies nowadays are trying to copy John Wick. Extraction is a borderline bad movie with just enough decent stuff to keep it from being bad. The one shot action set piece was admittedly kinda cool and Chris Hemsworth did do a good job with what he was given but everything else is so bland. The cinematography is bland, the action set pieces, minus the one take one, was bland and the characters were bland. The script was terrible and the story was so bloated and boring that I was scratching my head wondering why they made this movie 2 hours long. I would have been more lenient if the movie was at max an hour and a half long but 2 hours is pushing it. I would recommend passing on this unless you really want to watch it.

title: Sacrificing the plot and characters for action
text: I didn't expect much going into Extraction. Since it's directed by stunt coordinator Sam Hargrave, I had a feeling the action would be impressive and indeed it was but everything else was lacking in comparison.Extraction follows Tyler Rake, a mercenary who goes on a deadly extraction mission where he has to rescue a huge crime lord's kidnapped son.The biggest enjoyment you can get from Extraction is the action sequences. I have to give a huge amount of credit to everyone who worked on the choreography of the action. All the action scenes are brutal and look very realistic. There is this incredible 10 minute sequence that looks like it's done in one take which is any action lover's dream. The camerawork and stunts during that scene are really well done. I can't imagine the amount of time that would've been invested just on that one scene. I wish I could say the same for the script.If you're going to watch this film for the plot and characters, then you will be disappointed. The Russo Brothers, who made films like Avengers: Infinity War and Avengers: Endgame, wrote the screenplay and it's pretty bad. Apart from the action, there is nothing else to it. We barely learn about Hemsworth's character and the relationship between him and Jaiswal was extremely underdeveloped. This made it so difficult for me to care about them especially the end where it mattered. David Harbour is in the film but he didn't get to do much. He was completely wasted. There wasn't much to the villain either. A movie like John Wick has great action scenes as well but at the same time there is a good amount of character development within it.Extraction is very forgettable. The action is commendable but I've seen better in films like John Wick and The Raid. Chris Hemsworth and Randeep Hooda were good but the material they had to work with had a lot left to be desired.

title: .....Action packed but completely missed the Environment of Dhaka......
text: The premise of the movie was supposed to set in Dhaka, a city of 10+ million people in Bangladesh. Unfortunately, they completely missed mark making the set in Dhaka.To start with, the accent of the locals are wrong, they are speaking in an accent that's commonly used in West Bengal, India. Dhaka and People in Bangladesh, in General, have a completely different accent. Throughout the movie, Hindi songs are heard in the background, where everyone is watching tv during midday. People go to work here, Dhaka is the capital, nobody sits on their asses watching TV midday. Bangladesh has its own music industry, although the movie had some issues acquiring copyright for some of the songs to play in the background.The environment is wrong. Sure Dhaka has slums and dirty places, but most of the city is developed enough with an actual nice road system. If they set the scene somewhere else in Bangladesh, it would've been more convincing. The roads are basically dirt roads in this movie where Dhaka has one of the best road systems in the Country. Dhaka doesn't have that kinda dense jungle anywhere near the city, certainly not near the Buriganga river.The criminal class in Bangladesh is completely different. This isn't Africa, people don't employ child soldiers here. And certainly carry AK-47 in hand and in the open.The Police uniform and looks are completely misjudged. They are trying to portray the elite force of Bangladesh, Known as Rapid Action Battalion. They are not regular police. The deal with counter-terrorism and similar stuff. It should've been the police that deals with criminal or action in the street. Police vehicles are wrong.Don't get me wrong, the entire movie is brilliantly shot and exceptionally action-packed. But this provides a complete misrepresentation of Bangladesh, as well as the city of Dhaka. People who don't have an idea about Bangladesh will get a false sense for a beautiful country by the misrepresented set of this movie.Reviewed by oritroahmed

title: Extreme lack of research
text: As a citizen of Bangladesh, it is concerning to observe the portrayal depicted in this movie. There are several instances where the representation of Bangladesh's overall ambiance has been grossly misrepresented to global audiences. Firstly, Dhaka is depicted akin to war-torn, economically distressed regions like Iraq or Syria, which is far from the reality. Secondly, the constant portrayal of the police and army engaged solely in combating terrorism fosters a fictitious narrative. Thirdly, evident errors such as misspelling 'Bengali' on the poster, the exaggerated prominence of auto-rickshaws in the streetscape, inadequate portrayal of the Bengali language by Dhaka's criminals, and the misrepresentation of Dhaka residents' lifestyle and character as resembling those from another country are disconcerting. Such oversights raise questions about the director's attention to detail and cultural sensitivity.

title: Misrepresentation of Dhaka
text: Just watched the Netflix special "Extraction" starring Chris Hemsworth. I am extremely disappointed with the HORRIBLE misrepresentation of Dhaka. Dhaka AND its law enforcers deserve a MUCH better portrayal in front of the world. Reasons below (no spoilers on the storyline). #ExtractionIsNotDhaka1. Children don't carry rifles on the streets of Dhaka in broad daylight. It's a horrible misrepresentation shown in the movie. If I didn't live in Dhaka myself, I would be mistaken into thinking child terrorism is normal in Dhaka.2. Law enforcers in Dhaka - whether it be DMP, RAB or any of the defense organizations - are NOT incompetent and incapable of stopping two random guys flying in from outside the country. They do their job well, which is why we can go out, visit places, hang out with friends and more without worrying about random shootings (like they show in the movie).3. Dhaka's streets are NOT violent and it's NOT normal for people to fight in public with guns and swords. The movie made it seem like the people are used to things like these happening and somehow it's the norm here.4. An entire movie set to be in Dhaka and not a SINGLE major Bangladeshi character played by someone who SPEAKS the language and dialect that we do in Bangladesh? Are you for real, Netflix? All the major characters spoke Bengali like they do in West Bengal / Kolkata - NOT how we speak in Bangladesh - although they were representing characters in Bangladesh. Why? My mother was an actress, a lot of my friends are too. I'm sure many Bangladeshi actors could do those roles better than any of the ones who did, WHILE speaking our language/dialect.Overall, it's a horrible misrepresentation of the country in front of the world by a cast which isn't even 1% Bangladeshi. People abroad don't know a whole lot about Dhaka, but after they watch this movie, they might get the wrong impression that Dhaka lacks law enforcement and is filled with violence.This is not my Dhaka, this is not any Dhaka.PS: This is my opinion on the movie, as someone who was actually born and brought up in Dhaka.

title: Let me go ahead and extract this from my brain...
text:
SYNOPSIS:
Tyler Rake (Chris Hemsworth) is a black market mercenary who takes the mission to extract Ovi (Rudhraksh Jaiswal) from a powerful crime lord and return him to his father.REVIEW:
Not a huge fan of this one. I didn't rate this one too low, because there's potential at certain moments of the film. For example, there is a very cool continuous shot sequence near the beginning of the film when Tyler is in the process of extracting Ovi. The driving was a little distracting since you could get clearly tell he wasn't driving (I know that's obvious, but it shouldn't look obvious). A couple issues I had with the film is the sporadic writing and with the end of this film. There's also a female character, Nik, (Golshifteh Farahani) who seems to be close with Tyler, but there's no explanation of their past. They did announce working on a sequel, so maybe they'll explain there, but I digress. Wasn't my biggest qualm with the film. For me, that came with the end of the film. I understand dragging emotional sequences out, but when someone should be dead, they should die. Not everyone is Superman out here. There's only one to my knowledge. Maybe there are more supermen. Maybe this was a Superman prequel idk. Either way, the film wasn't horrible, but I'm not itching for that sequel. 5.9/10.

title: Action becomes boringly routine, no plot, unfair to Bangladesh
text:
I didn't have high expectations for this movie, but I figured a Chris Hemsworth action pic would provide a couple hours of diverting of pulp entertainment.
Where did it go wrong for me?
The action scenes were well choreographed with lots of fiery explosions, chases & hand to hand combat etc, but about half way through the film it got to the point where it became cartoonish & mechanical. The swarms of bad guys were inept & couldn't shoot straight to the point where it was hard to believe our hero was in any real danger, whatever the odds. It all became very predicable & mind numbing.
The plot is weak, even for pulp. The story revolves around a kidnapping, the reason for which is never really established. Hemsworths character is a walking "mercenary with a painful past" clich√©. The quiet, intimate scenes meant to show his humanity are painfully, awkwardly done, as unbelievable as the overdone action sequences and feel like pro forma filler. Too many unbelievable coincidences. Very senseless & disjointed.
Having said all that, I might have given this film a "5" as an action pic if it wasn't for its arbitrary and misleading setting in Bangladesh. As I watched the film I kept thinking that the portrayal of the of city Dhaka is very harsh. Criminals controlling the army & police, a dirty, filthy city, gangs roaming the streets, including kids with AKs - basically Somalia at its worst. And wondered why would Bangladesh allow a film to be shot in Dhaka when it portrays it in such a negative light?
Well, the answer I soon learned is that this film was written, produced and shot in India by Indians and there are no Bengalis at all in the cast. Now there's no reason the plot couldn't have been set in a city in India, other than of course the Indian producers didn't want one of their own cities to be shown as dirty, dangerous, violent, lawless and corrupt. So they moved the whole thing next door to Bangladesh. Never mind that there's no objective evidence that Dhaka is anything like it's portrayed in the film, or for that matter, any worse than cities in India. Just dump the whole dirty, lawless mess on the people across the border.
I have to wonder if the fact that India now has a Hindu nationalist led government and Bangladesh is 90% Muslim played a factor in all this too.
Thumbs down on Netflix and Chris Hemsworth for their association with this tainted picture.
(BTW, I have no personal connection to either country.)

title: John Wick-esque action scenes with a Bollywood Film Plot
text:
I had high hopes for this one because of the star studded cast. Not only they dropped the ball on recreating Dhaka city, somewhere in India, the plot also has major conveniences. In a movie where you have the titular stars like Chris Hemsworth, David Harbour and critically acclaimed actors like Randeep Hooda and Pankaj Tripathi ( I would call it a cameo), a little more research on the place where most of the story takes place would have been more appreciated. Indonesia sure knows how to make a badass action flick with lesser known cast and half the budget. I would rather prefer The Night Comes For Us among Netflix's action packed offerings.
This movie is only watchable as a one time pop corn flick as it does not have too many redeeming qualities.

title: Some nice Cinematography in a bland copy paste thriller
text:
The one redeeming quality this movie has was the cinematography. Some of the scenes are very well constructed including the epic 11 minute 'one shot' part following the characters around in the chase. Having said that, I wasn't a fan of the widescreen which felt very claustrophobic or the constant orange filter because I obviously need reminding that Bangladesh is a hot place.
I thought the characterisation was barely noticeable. You don't learn much about them and when they're being sad or determined, the viewer hasn't been put in a position to empathize with them.
Chris Hemsworth was a decent enough actor for a 'merc' but the part needed a lot more fleshing out in the script to make his character have more prestige. In other words, he needed a (better) backstory, a clearer motive and a personality!The narrative felt like it was pasting tropes from other movies it had copied from. You get very typical chases, car stunts, twists and 'military movie conventions' sloppily thrown in if you ask me.I see on the grapevine that a sequel is possible...oh dear...

title: Not Bad Not Good
text:

The backstory isn't convincing enough, the supporting characters have no scope, they just fall like Dominos with no value other than just being part of itYou wouldn't regret watching it, nothing to say it's a must watch either.(The comparison of this with Taken, Man on Fire, John Wick are pure exaggeration, don't fall for it)

title: Lack of research; Poor story & Misrepresentation of a country.
text:
As the whole movie is based on stunt and action scene one cannot complain about those that is for sure but when the cons take over the cons then the rating goes down.Pros:
(3 stars for that)(1 stars for that)Cons:
(- 2 stars for each so -6 stars in total)* A movie portraying recent time should be portraying the recent scenario of the city portrayed. There comes the whole disappointment. Not as a Bangladeshi but as movie freak I am saying this. If you are showing a part of city it is okay to portray as however one wants but if the whole city is portrayed it should be taken into consideration how it should be portrayed. In this movie whole Dhaka is shown as slam/dirty area with narrow lanes which is definitely funny and ridiculous. Yes it is over populated but the whole city is not based on old buildings and narrow lanes or smelly sewer. Only the part of old town has old buildings with narrow lanes.* Dhaka is not a post war country and children do not run with guns in open streets, they dont even carry guns in a hidden manner and they are not part of gangs for sure.* Even if it is considered the whole armed forces are corrupt in a country but what about the background story for that one? I don't know, they might have plan to produce another movie for the past story.
In movie there is no local showed to help the character Tyler or Saju which is actually a serious negative side according to me. For Saju how he entered inside Dhaka without help form someone how he crossed border with arms and without security people knowing that is a mystery.* We all know the difference of English accent between UK and USA, what if a movie story is based on USA and the actors portraying USA locals are using UK accent, how horrible does that sound?
Same has happened in this movie (Except these two character: Dhaka Elite force Commander and Farhad), even the character portraying Dhaka Drag Lord, Amir Asif cannot speak proper Bangla, how funny is that?) The other actors portraying Dhaka goons are using West Bengal accent (Part of india, Bangla is their mother tongue too) which is too much different than the actual accent of Bangladeshi one.*Then comes background songs used in the scene.
All the songs played on background are Hindi (Might have been copyright issues but there are too many West Bengal produced Bangla Music?)
Seriously? this is the research of a movie team!!!!

title: Absolute Wrong Plot
text:
I am from Bangladesh. I have been living in Dhaka City ( the real one) for last 36 years. After watching the movie, I think i should speak for my city.1. Movie casting was very good. Chris Hemsworth, Randeep Hooda , the kid everyone showed their skills while the director completely lacks his. It is not DHAKA AT ALL. I really doubt if they have seen the city even by google.
2. " Sultana Kamal Bridge" is way ahead from Dhaka city.
3.The accent heard in background seems absolutely wrong- I have never ever heard of this accent enywhere in Bangladesh for the last 36 years - I am also wondering how it occured.
4. Bollywood songs in background (which is also pretty old, like 90's) might confuse the viewer as well. We have our own music.
5. Children were shown in the street carrying guns and using foul languages- really? Which Dhaka is it?
6. Finer detail- the city environment, bakcground activity, vehicle models used for the movie- nothing matches Bangladesh even- let alone " Dhaka City".Bottom liine-
The movie lacks its context completely. Dhaka is a peaceful city.
Overcrowded ? - yes.
Heavy Traffic ?- yes
Air Pollution ? - yes
Noisey? - yes
But it is vibrant in its own way- much safer than many cities of the world. We can find child begger in the street - but definitely not terrorist.I suggest anyone related to this movie should type " Dhaka" in Google or Wikipedia. They have more information - especially authentic one.I sincerely apologise for my comments above if it hurts anyone. Any city shown in any movie should reflect its own character - imagination shall be there for sure- but definitely not out of context .

title: Netflix Continues to Corner Market on Lousy Action Flicks
text: Even before the world, cinemas included, closed for business during the current pandemic, the economics of going to theatres to see movies had become increasingly limited--mostly relying on tent-pole franchise installments. Disney owns a huge chunk of this business with childhood fare: remakes of their cartoons, MCU superheroes, etc. Not only have these new dynamics largely squeezed out the mid-budget drama from multiplexes, but also the traditional, usually stand-alone, macho action flicks such as "Extraction," and "Bright" (2017), and "Triple Frontier," and "Red Sea Diving Resort," and "6 Underground" (all 2019). Now, if it's not already part of a series, chances are you'll only get this lack-of-a-brand type of adrenaline injection from streaming services and at home. Unfortunately, "Extraction" is a mostly generic burger of a movie from MCU veterans taking a break before making "Avengers 83," or whatever.Stunt choreographer Sam Hargrave gets a chance to direct, and his background in filming fighting moves, along with the similar skills of the Russo brothers and Thor himself, Chris Hemsworth, shows. The next movie I saw after this one was "Angel Has Fallen" (2019), and it's painfully clear that the makers here put care into their craft, whereas the hacks behind the other one, despite it getting a wide theatrical release before making its way to Netflix, were merely there to cash checks. So, I do appreciate the action scenes here--especially the virtuoso, lengthy one-shot car chase.Otherwise, though, "Extraction" is a lousy entry in the trope of the White Savior. Others have commented how poorly the picture represents Dhaka, which just demonstrates how little filmmakers of white-savoir rubbish care about depicting the racial other. Narratively, only the white male hero's journey is made to matter--how sympathetic he is to the supposed plight of the Oriental, as opposed to their actual state of affairs or characterizations. Blah, I prefer my white-savior myths to have some knowing humor and time-traveling, purple Malthusian giants. If for little else, "Extraction" is helpful for realizing how much I miss fat Thor.

title: Nonsensical plot and clearly sends out the wrong message
text: Let me sum up the theme of this movie in a few words: a drug lord's son gets kidnapped by another drug lord and a mercenary is sent to rescue this kid. The kidnapper apparently controls the entire army, elite forces and police of a nation. If that is not ridiculous enough, the mercenary shoots these trained soldiers down like flies (probably around 100 of them single-handedly). Yep we are supposed to believe these trained individuals cannot shoot straight and are no match for a mercenary. Apparently a nation's defense forces are the villains and we are supposed to sympathise with a mercenary and a drug lord's son!Morale of the story: you can be a hero if you are a mercenary or drug lord's son, no need to sign up for the armed forces because they are just inept. This is the kind of nonsensical stuff our movies promote these days. Just outrageous.Only positive: some cool action scenes

title: Would Have Been a B Movie
text: This would have been a B movie if Hemsworth wasn't in it. Alot of action scenes, actually way too many, and in my opinion a horrible ending. The story line is the generic fight your way out of a bad situation while multiple bad guys are after you scenario, which you see is hundreds of B movies each year. Not a fan.

Lastly poor bangla dialogues. It was more like kolkata version of Bangla and this is not how Bangladeshi people speak. Total disappointment.

title: Dreadful.
text:
Easily the worst action film I have ever seen. Truly, utterly, comprehensively awful.
We watched this film because my wife likes looking at Chris Hemsworth but how it scored as high as it has is a total mystery.
I managed to watch the whole film but I never cared if the hero lived or died - or indeed any of the characters.
The body count must be easily over 500 and really, the whole film is just a relentless series of scenes where people die violently and pointlessly.
Don't ever bother watching it. it is pure and unadulterated rubbish. Truly awful.
Pity.
I don't fancy Hemsworth but I usually like his films. Not this one.

title: Complete misrepresentation of a Country
text:
Bangladesh is NOT a violent country but a peace loving country. They don't have that kind of crime lords in that country and there is no violence over there as shown in the movie. I understand it's Hollywood but you can't misrepresent a country like that. It's NOT a fictional country like " Wakanda ". You can't hurt peoples emotion and love for their country. You have to remember, Bangladesh is one of the biggest contributor of United Nations peacekeeping mission for a long time.Ohh... I forgot... The movie... No... Not worth watching. No story, average action. If you like Steven Seagal or his movies ( i don't know if anybody does ) then you might like it. Just like Steven Seagal's movies, there's a lot of camera movement but not much of actual acting or action happening there. They just tried to make the scenes epic by moving their cameras like crazy instead of letting the actors actually act.
Overall, if you are looking for a good or maybe OK movies, it's not a movie you want to watch.

title: No
text:
Lack of plot and character depth, huge lack of cultural accuracy, hiring big named actor to carry out the action, which reminds the only "satisfaction" and selling point while sticking to a shallow movie.
If you want a movie with similar plot lines and scenery based on a real person, actual complex characters with layered acting, decent action and lots of intensity and good twists in the plot, I recommend another Netflix original "Close" with Noomi Rapace (The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo) and great supporting by Sophie N√©lisse (The Book Thief). It's criminally underrated for one being a female action drama/thriller which people will always be nitpicking about opposite movies like this one starting out at a solid 7.4. What? That's higher rating than Die Hard 2 and almost the same as Skyfall. Not to get started on "6 Underground" coming in with 6.1 solid stars with its big names not even making up for the lack of so many quality-based things, putting an emphasis on "empty action and looks". Really gonna continue to do this, are we?
Watch this one if you want decent action and with a big-named celebrity, not really caring about anything else. Then you'll be satisfied for sure.

title: As a Bangladeshi, I am disappointed
text: We Bangladeshi people get exited when we get international attention and it doesn't involve building collapse killing thousands or something like that.
